Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Dynamic Net Analyte Signal Modeling for Multivariate Calibration and Maintenance
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program, and co-funding from the Office of Cyberinfrastructure "Venture Fund," Professor John Kalivas of Idaho State University is developing five pioneering calibration tools to advance chemical analysis. Calibration generally involves forming a mathematical relationship between chemical concentration and an instrumental response such as spectroscopic data. It is critical to numerous disciplines, including process analytical technology for the pharmaceutical and chemical industries, environmental and agriculture monitoring, and medical diagnostics. The Kalivas group seeks to design calibrations which eliminate chemical analysis interferences and offer less costly and more accurate and precise chemical analyses. Two statistical/analytical tools are used: Tikhonov regularization and net analyte signal. The improvements targeted by this project should benefit many disciplines by enabling better calibrations that are stable over extended periods of time.

By participating in this research, undergraduate students learn state-of-the-art calibration and become proficient at performing collaborative scientific research. Education of undergraduates in these advanced methods prepares them for subsequent scientific professional pursuits. Another key impact of this project is development of classroom software tools for use in the curriculum at Idaho State University and other institutions. Additionally, disseminating the innovative calibration and curricular software through Professor Kalivas' web site allows newcomers and practitioners direct access, assuring software re-use. Co-funding from the OCI-Venture Fund specifically seeks to enhance such efforts in CI-reuse and long term software sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In analytical chemistry, calibration deals with forming a mathematical relationship (a model) between instrumental signals (measurements) and quantitative and qualitative information for an analyte. For example, the concentration of the active pharmaceutical ingredient (analyte) in a tablet is quantitative information and authentication of the origin of a food product (analyte), such as where an extra virgin olive oil is from, is qualitative information. The phrase “net analyte signal” (NAS) is an important concept in analytical chemistry and the NAS is that part of the instrumental signal useful for the analysis. This project developed novel mathematical process to maximize the NAS thereby providing improved calibrations for more accurate and precise results.

The research was accomplished by 18 undergraduates. Some research also involved collaboration with a community college professor and university professors in Spain, Hungary, and Greece. The Spanish collaboration involved two undergraduates traveling to Spain to research in the laboratories with a graduate student. This international experience promoted cross-fertilization of ideas between investigators, institutions, and countries. Images are provided. As a result of their research efforts, all undergraduates have become keenly adept at calibration methods. From this training, the students also developed lifelong cognitive research skills to assist them in graduate school and/or their careers.

The project generated 13 papers, one book chapter, and 29 national and international meeting presentations.  There are three manuscripts in preparation. Of the papers and manuscripts, 12 dealt with the mathematical methodology developments and 4 were on application problems solved by the new methods.

The project focus involved developing new approaches for the universal problem of “domain adaption” where a calibration model formed for an existing situation (set of measurement conditions) must be adapted (updated) to now work in new conditions. For example, adapting a model to: work on a different instrument, correctly analyze wheat samples of a different species, determine the soil organic content of a sample from a new geographical location, or determine the origin of a food product grown in a new season. A number of adaption methods were created that succeeded at these tasks.

Of the several new NAS approaches developed, one allowed for “greener” chemical analysis in certain situations. In this method, only a sample of the substance to be analyzed (analyte) in pure form and samples without the analyte are needed thereby eliminating the need for expensive and hazard waste forming sample preparations. A common example of where this approach is valuable is quantitative analysis of the active pharmaceutical ingredient in a tablet. Tablets can be made of the pure drug as well as tablets at any time in new conditions with the drug. This process allows easy domain adaption without the need of expensive and time consuming reference methods.

One of the spinoff projects extended work to create an improved process to determine relationships between samples. For example, before a calibration can be performed, the samples must be cleaned for “outliers” where an outlier sample is one that is unique and can harm the calibration. A sample can be unique for various reasons, the most common is laboratory operator error in preparing and/or measuring the sample. An image is provided on the process.

With the purchase of new computers as part of the project, the research laboratory facilities have improved. New computer algorithms have been developed and written for variants of domain adaption problems.
